verses.text: The sons of the prophets said to Elisha, 'See, the place where we dwell with you is too crowded for us.'
verses.comment: The sons of the prophets are part of a prophetic community, gathered around Elisha as their spiritual leader, which prefigures later communal monastic life.

verses.text: 'Let us go to the Jordan, and each of us will get a log, and let us make a place there where we may dwell.' And he answered, 'Go.'
verses.comment: Building together demonstrates unity and community values, hinting at the importance of spiritual fellowship.

verses.text: Then one of them said, 'Please come with your servants.' And he answered, 'I will go.'
verses.comment: Elisha’s presence is considered essential, emphasizing the necessity of spiritual authority and guidance in communal actions.

verses.text: So he went with them. And when they came to the Jordan, they began to cut down trees.
verses.comment: Jordan is often a place of significant encounters in scripture, including the Israelites’ crossing (Joshua 3) and Jesus’ baptism (Matt 3:13), showing God's work through physical locations.

verses.text: But as one was cutting down a log, the iron axe head fell into the water, and he cried out and said, 'Alas, my master! It was borrowed!'
verses.comment: The borrowed axe head’s loss points to concern for stewardship and responsibility—values that are part of living virtuously.

verses.text: And the man of God said, 'Where did it fall?' And he showed him the place. Then he cut off a stick and threw it there, and made the iron float.
verses.comment: The miracle recalls Moses’ wonders, demonstrating not only Elisha’s authority but also the transformative power of God working through His appointed servant.

verses.text: 'Pick it up,' he said. So he reached out his hand and took it.
verses.comment: The recipient actively receives the miracle, hinting at cooperation between human activity and divine grace.

verses.text: Once, the king of Aram was at war with Israel. He consulted with his servants, saying, 'My camp will be in such-and-such a place.'
verses.comment: Hostility against Israel from Aram sets the scene for God’s protection of His people through the prophet.

verses.text: But the man of God sent word to the king of Israel, 'Beware that you do not pass this place, for the Arameans are going down there.'
verses.comment: Elisha protects Israel by supernatural knowledge, reflecting God’s special care through prophetic mediation.

verses.text: The king of Israel sent to the place of which the man of God had told him, and he warned him; and he guarded himself there, not just once or twice.
verses.comment: Repeated deliverance reveals a sustained relationship between the prophet and the king, akin to spiritual oversight.

verses.text: Therefore the king of Aram became greatly troubled by this; he called his servants and said to them, 'Will you not show me which of us is for the king of Israel?'
verses.comment: The Aramean king suspects betrayal, but the reality is divine protection—a theme throughout scripture (Dan. 6:22).

verses.text: One of his servants said, 'No, my lord, O king. But Elisha, the prophet who is in Israel, tells the king of Israel the words that you speak in your bedroom.'
verses.comment: Elisha participates in God’s omniscience, showing the intimate knowledge God has of everyone’s actions.

verses.text: He said, 'Go and see where he is, that I may send and seize him.' It was told to him, 'Behold, he is in Dothan.'
verses.comment: Dothan is also where Joseph was betrayed, connecting themes of divine providence (Gen. 37).

verses.text: So he sent there horses, chariots, and a great army. They came by night and surrounded the city.
verses.comment: The earthly host surrounds Elisha, but the coming verses show the superiority of the spiritual host.

verses.text: When the servant of the man of God got up early and went out, he saw the army with horses and chariots surrounding the city. And he said, 'Alas, my master! What shall we do?'
verses.comment: The servant’s anxiety sets up a teaching moment on faith and the unseen reality.

verses.text: He answered, 'Do not be afraid, for those who are with us are more than those who are with them.'
verses.comment: This principle of trusting in God’s victorious strength is a thread throughout scripture, fulfilled in Christ’s ultimate victory (see Rom 8:31).

verses.text: Elisha prayed and said, 'Lord, I pray, open his eyes so that he may see.' Then the Lord opened the servant's eyes, and he saw, and behold, the mountain was full of horses and chariots of fire all around Elisha.
verses.comment: The vision of angelic hosts reveals the reality of spiritual warfare and the protection given to God’s faithful servants.

verses.text: And when the Arameans came down to him, Elisha prayed to the Lord and said, 'Strike this people, please, with blindness.' So He struck them with blindness, according to the word of Elisha.
verses.comment: Physical blindness here parallels spiritual blindness, an important theme—contrast with Christ’s restoring of sight (John 9).

verses.text: And Elisha said to them, 'This is not the way nor the city; follow me, and I will bring you to the man whom you seek.' But he led them to Samaria.
verses.comment: Elisha’s leading is reminiscent of spiritual guidance—pointing to the shepherding role fulfilled in Christ.

verses.text: When they entered Samaria, Elisha said, 'Lord, open the eyes of these men, that they may see.' So the Lord opened their eyes, and they saw that they were inside Samaria.
verses.comment: Opening of eyes symbolizes spiritual awakening, a theme continued in the New Testament (Luke 24:31).

verses.text: When the king of Israel saw them, he said to Elisha, 'Father, should I strike them? Should I strike them?'
verses.comment: Calling Elisha ‘father’ emphasizes the spiritual fatherhood—showing the value of wise leadership in God’s people.

verses.text: He answered, 'You shall not strike them. Would you strike those whom you have taken captive with your sword and your bow? Set bread and water before them, so that they may eat and drink and go to their master.'
verses.comment: Mercy shown to enemies echoes Christ’s teaching in the Sermon on the Mount about loving one’s enemies (Matt 5:44).

verses.text: So he prepared a great feast for them; after they ate and drank, he sent them away, and they went back to their master. And the armies of Aram did not come again into the land of Israel.
verses.comment: The feast given to enemies prefigures the superabundance of grace offered in Christ, and reconciliation rather than warfare.

verses.text: Afterward, Ben-Hadad king of Aram gathered all his army, and went up and besieged Samaria.
verses.comment: Despite mercy, further human conflict arises, showing the persistent brokenness needing ultimate redemption.

verses.text: There was a great famine in Samaria, and they besieged it so that a donkey's head was sold for eighty shekels of silver, and a quarter of a kab of dove's dung for five shekels of silver.
verses.comment: The extremity of famine fulfills warning passages from the Torah about covenant unfaithfulness (Lev 26).

verses.text: As the king of Israel passed by on the wall, a woman cried out to him, saying, 'Help, my lord, O king!'
verses.comment: Dire need in Israel echoes moments of crisis in the Bible, often preceding divine intervention.

verses.text: He said, 'If the Lord does not help you, how can I help you? From the threshing floor, or from the winepress?'
verses.comment: The king acknowledges reliance on God’s intervention, similar to the need for divine providence in all ages.

verses.text: Then the king asked her, 'What is your complaint?' She answered, 'This woman said to me, "Give your son, that we may eat him today, and we will eat my son tomorrow."'
verses.comment: Cannibalism as consequence of judgment was foretold as a curse for disobedience (Deut 28:57), underlining the severe state of Israel.

verses.text: So we cooked my son and ate him. The next day I said to her, "Give your son, that we may eat him"; but she hid her son.
verses.comment: The horror described here matches lamentation and judgment motifs, contrasting later Christian banquets of spiritual nourishment.

verses.text: When the king heard the woman’s words, he tore his clothes; and as he passed by on the wall, the people saw that he wore sackcloth underneath, next to his skin.
verses.comment: Sackcloth signals penitence and grief, the proper disposition needed for restoration.

verses.text: He said, 'May God do so to me and more also, if the head of Elisha the son of Shaphat remains on him today.'
verses.comment: The king blames God’s representative, a common misdirection in times of suffering. Yet, divine authority remains crucial in spiritual guidance.

verses.text: Now Elisha sat in his house, and the elders were sitting with him. The king sent a man from before him; but before the messenger arrived, Elisha said to the elders, 'Do you see how this murderer has sent someone to take off my head? But, when the messenger comes, shut the door and hold it fast against him. Is not the sound of his master’s feet behind him?'
verses.comment: Elisha’s gathering of elders mirrors authoritative spiritual councils, upholding continuity of spiritual tradition.

verses.text: While he was still speaking with them, the messenger came down to him; and the king said, 'Surely this disaster is from the Lord. Why should I wait for the Lord any longer?'
verses.comment: Impatience with suffering contrasts with faithful waiting, a theme and spiritual discipline taught throughout Scripture.
